prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: As already explained, we wish to study the outflowing gas from massive YSOs, which requires resolving line wings as broad as several km/s. Smoothing the spectra to a resolution of 1.5 km/s will hence suffice for our purposes. The correlator setup has been chosen in such a way to cover the HCO+ and H13CO+ (1-0), and the SiO(2-1) rotational transitions with about 0.4 km/s resolution. We will also cover the CS(2-1), HCN and H13CN(1-0) lines with similar resolution, which may be useful to study the quiescent gas of the clump pierced by the jet/outflow. A broad 2 GHz bandwidth with limited spectral resolution (3.4 km/s) is necessary to obtain a sensitive continuum map, which will be interesting in itself and necessary for continuum subtraction.

As previously explained, 1.5 arcsec resolution is needed to investigate the interface between the known radio jets and the molecular outflows to be studied with the present proposal. The outflow lobes in the HCO+(1-0) line should not exceed a few 10 arcsec at the typical distance of our targets (4 kpc), and in any case we are not interested in the possible pc-scale structure of the outflow. Thus a maximum angular scale of 40 arcsec is amply sufficient for our aims.

We wish to image the HCO+ and H13CO+ (1-0), and SiO(2-1) lines with a spectral resolution of 1.5 km/s and an angular resolution of at least 1.5 arcsec. Since we are interested in the line wings and the typical line FWHM in high-mass star forming regions is about 5 km/s, we believe that 1.5 km/s resolution will suffice for our purposes. The angular resolution must be sufficient to resolve regions comparable to the size of the radio jets (a few arcsec), which we have imaged with the JVLA at cm wavelengths. Therefore, we estimate that 1.5 arcsec is a good compromise between resolution and sensitivity. The S/N estimate is led by the expected emission in the wings of the HCO+ and SiO lines. Based on previous literature studies, we consider 2 K a representative, conservative value, which implies that a 1sigma RMS noise of 0.2 K is required to attain a S/N=10 in the wings, which will permit us to obtain sensitive maps of the outflow lobes.

As already explained, we wish to study the outflowing gas from massive YSOs, which requires resolving line wings as broad as several km/s. Smoothing the spectra to a resolution of 1.5 km/s will hence suffice for our purposes. The correlator setup has been chosen in such a way to cover the HCO+ and H13CO+ (1-0), and the SiO(2-1) rotational transitions with about 0.4 km/s resolution. We will also cover the CS(2-1), HCN and H13CN(1-0) lines with similar resolution, which may be useful to study the quiescent gas of the clump pierced by the jet/outflow. A broad 2 GHz bandwidth with limited spectral resolution (3.4 km/s) is necessary to obtain a sensitive continuum map, which will be interesting in itself and necessary for continuum subtraction.

As previously explained, 1.5 arcsec resolution is needed to investigate the interface between the known radio jets and the molecular outflows to be studied with the present proposal. The outflow lobes in the HCO+(1-0) line should not exceed a few 10 arcsec at the typical distance of our targets (4 kpc), and in any case we are not interested in the possible pc-scale structure of the outflow. Thus a maximum angular scale of 40 arcsec is amply sufficient for our aims.

We wish to image the HCO+ and H13CO+ (1-0), and SiO(2-1) lines with a spectral resolution of 1.5 km/s and an angular resolution of at least 1.5 arcsec. Since we are interested in the line wings and the typical line FWHM in high-mass star forming regions is about 5 km/s, we believe that 1.5 km/s resolution will suffice for our purposes. The angular resolution must be sufficient to resolve regions comparable to the size of the radio jets (a few arcsec), which we have imaged with the JVLA at cm wavelengths. Therefore, we estimate that 1.5 arcsec is a good compromise between resolution and sensitivity. The S/N estimate is led by the expected emission in the wings of the HCO+ and SiO lines. Based on previous literature studies, we consider 2 K a representative, conservative value, which implies that a 1sigma RMS noise of 0.2 K is required to attain a S/N=10 in the wings, which will permit us to obtain sensitive maps of the outflow lobes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have performed a deep continuum survey with the JVLA at 6 and 1.3 cm, towards a sample of 60 high-mass star-forming cores. These belong to 3 different types that we believe to correspond to different evolutionary phases: hot molecular cores (HMCs), cold molecular cores with mid-IR emission (CMC-IRs), and without mid-IR emission (CMCs). Indeed, we find that free-free emission is detected only in 1 CMC out of 18 (6%), whereas detection rates of 53% and 91% are obtained respectively for CMC-IRs and HMCs, consistent with an age increase from CMCs to HMCs. Since in most cases the cm continuum emission has spectral index of 0.2-1 between 5 and 22 GHz and jet-like morphology, we conclude that we have identified a sample of thermal jets from massive young stellar objects (MYSOs). This is ideal to study the evolution of jet/outflow systems in the early stages of high-mass star formation. Our goal is to resolve the molecular outflows associated with a selected sample of 10 CMC-IRs and HMCs, and determine their physical parameters. By comparing the properties of the outflows of the two sub-samples (CMC-IRs and HMCs), we will determine how the outflow properties change with time in MYSOs.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, New Mexico Tech

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, New Mexico Tech
Center of Radio Astronomy and Astrophysics , Mexico, National Autonomous University of
